description.narrative: The objectives of the intervention is to support the election processes in Afghanistan by providing support to IEC (Independent Election Commission), support the democratic institutions in the country and strengthening the ability for women to influence society.
UNDP - stöd till uppbyggnad av valkommissionen
UNDP - support to the election comission

description.narrative:
Examples of results achieved are: 1.The adoption of Afghanistans Electoral Law; and Law on Structure, Duties and Authorities of the IEC and Independent Electoral Complaints Commission (IECC) in June 2013 enabled Afghanistan to conduct elections according to an official legal framework, for the first time in its history. Diverse and Inclusive Candidacy - The IEC facilitated the nomination of 27 Presidential candidates and 2,713 Provincial Council candidates, among whom 11 percent were women the greatest proportion of female candidates in Afghanistans election history. Improved Fraud Mitigation Based on the findings of an external study, the IEC employed a comprehensive approach to fraud mitigation including the application of technical measures at each stage of the process, strengthening recruitment and training of electoral staff, and conducting extensive civil/voter education campaigns. Evidence suggests that this approach was extremely efficient. Coordination with National Institutions - Information sharing and close coordination with ANSF enabled the IEC to maximise enfranchisement while avoiding unnecessary exposure to security risks. Cooperation with the Ministries of Hajj and Womens Affairs (MOWA) enabled Mullahs to serve as advocates in their communities, addressing both men and women and emphasising of the importance of full participation. According to a post-election survey, 86 percent of respondents agreed that elections are compatible with Islam in comparison to just 77 percent in 2013. Civil Society Advocates In advance of the first round of elections, the IEC engaged civil society organisations (CSOs) to participate in public information-sharing. By printing twice its usual volume of election information materials and disseminating half through CSOs, the IEC effectively doubled its reach. National observers were more numerous than in any election before (14,585); included a greater proportion of women than any other group accredited (32 percent).
On Election Day, a total of 6,604, 456 valid ballots were cast, including 36 percent by women. Even more Afghans participated in the run-off election, when a total of 7,120,585 valid ballots were cast, including 37 percent by women. Inclusive Participation In addition to their remarkable turnout (which was greater than in any other election since 2004), women were actively involved as election staff and candidates, accounting for 43 percent of Civic/Voter Educator Trainers; 34 percent of voter registration staff; 31 percent of Civic/Voter Educators (CVEs); and 32 percent of national observers. Women represented a greater proportion of Provincial Council candidates (11 percent) than ever before and won 21 percent of the seats available. Of the 97 winning female candidates, 18 would have won their seats even without the advantage of the gender quota; and three received more votes than any of their male competitors evidencing public confidence in the ability of women to assume leadership roles. Electoral Capacity Although the IEC received less financial, technical and operational support than ever before, the 2014 Presidential and Parliamentary Elections were fully Afghanled and Afghan owned. According to the 2014 mid-term review, As a technical exercise, the IEC proved itself capable of planning and conducting the countries first independent Presidential Election. These successes are a testament to the capacity development and operational support provided
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
